body:
Kubernetes 1.0.3 does not work with `Virtual Box 5.0.0 r101573` and gives the following error message:

```
kubernetes> echo $KUBERNETES_PROVIDER 
vagrant
kubernetes> ./cluster/kube-up.sh 
Starting cluster using provider: vagrant
... calling verify-prereqs
... calling kube-up
Using credentials: vagrant:vagrant
No usable default provider could be found for your system.

Vagrant relies on interactions with 3rd party systems, known as
"providers", to provide Vagrant with resources to run development
environments. Examples are VirtualBox, VMware, Hyper-V.

The easiest solution to this message is to install VirtualBox, which
is available for free on all major platforms.

If you believe you already have a provider available, make sure it
is properly installed and configured. You can see more details about
why a particular provider isn't working by forcing usage with
`vagrant up --provider=PROVIDER`, which should give you a more specific
error message for that particular provider.
```

Using the `curl` command also gives similar error:

```
 curl -sS https://get.k8s.io | bash
Downloading kubernetes release v1.0.1 to /Users/arungupta/tools/kubernetes.tar.gz
--2015-08-12 15:19:23--  https://storage.googleapis.com/kubernetes-release/release/v1.0.1/kubernetes.tar.gz
Resolving storage.googleapis.com... 216.58.216.176, 2607:f8b0:400a:807::2010
Connecting to storage.googleapis.com|216.58.216.176|:443... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK
Length: 118107384 (113M) [application/x-tar]
Saving to: 'kubernetes.tar.gz'

kubernetes.tar.gz                   100%[=====================================================================>] 112.64M  6.83MB/s   in 60s    

2015-08-12 15:20:23 (1.88 MB/s) - 'kubernetes.tar.gz' saved [118107384/118107384]

Unpacking kubernetes release v1.0.1
Creating a kubernetes on vagrant...
Starting cluster using provider: vagrant
... calling verify-prereqs
... calling kube-up
Using credentials: vagrant:vagrant
No usable default provider could be found for your system.

Vagrant relies on interactions with 3rd party systems, known as
"providers", to provide Vagrant with resources to run development
environments. Examples are VirtualBox, VMware, Hyper-V.

The easiest solution to this message is to install VirtualBox, which
is available for free on all major platforms.

If you believe you already have a provider available, make sure it
is properly installed and configured. You can see more details about
why a particular provider isn't working by forcing usage with
`vagrant up --provider=PROVIDER`, which should give you a more specific
error message for that particular provider.
```

This is broken!

labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to documentation.
labels.name: kind/documentation

labels.description: Must be staffed and worked on either currently, or very soon, ideally in time for the next release.
labels.name: priority/important-soon

title: Kubernetes 1.0.3 does not work with VirtualBox 5.0.0
